awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Computer Aided Design Toolkit for Desktop Digital Fabrication of Circuits on Paper
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project is to increase the diversity of people engaging in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) by broadening the creative and expressive possibilities at the intersection of craft and circuit design.  The project hypothesizes that by creating design and digital fabrication tools that leverage familiar paper craft practices and the intrinsic motivational value the arts, circuit design and fabrication can be made accessible to those who are novices to circuit design and fabrication.  Research shows that this approach is especially successful for reaching those who otherwise may not participate in STEM, especially underrepresented minorities, girls and women. By developing software to support digital circuit design and fabrication, this project enables users to easily share and build off of digital design templates, expanding the reach of beginner-friendly starter projects and creating a community of learners who can co-create and co-teach. Further, by enabling creators to connect circuit design to consumer-friendly digital fabrication technologies like desktop craft cutters, we will bring the digital manufacturing of electronics out of traditionally technical environments and into entirely new and more mainstream audiences.

The technical innovation is the development of novel electrical design software that greatly reduces the complexity of existing electronics computer aided design tools, making the tool accessible to novice users such as educators, hobbyists and artists.  This will be done through the elimination of schematic abstractions along with powerful simulation capabilities uniquely catered for expressive and artistic technological creations.  By combining beginner-appropriate electronic footprints with a drawing interface for sketching traces, users will be able to represent their designs exactly as they would appear when built.  By incorporating electrical rule checks along with simulation of circuit behavior, the software will allow users to iterate on their designs with confidence before they invest time in fabricating. To address these challenges, the design of the software and accompanying physical toolkit will be designed iteratively and in close partnership with K-12 educators and hobby crafters through a series of user studies to ensure that the intended audience who have never used electronic design software before can manufacture their designs easily while being able to express their diverse interests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
For this Phase I project, Chibitronics prototyped Circuit Sketcher, a browser-based software tool for the digital design and digital fabrication of circuits on paper.  During Phase I, we met our proposed technical objectives: 1) Designing and developing a circuit design tool for building circuits on paper, 2) Designing and assembling a toolkit of physical materials and instructional materials and 3) Conducting user studies with educators, students, and paper crafters.  We achieved all three of these objectives.  Our participants found Circuit Sketcher to be an accessible and versatile tool for circuit design and fabrication, enabling creative expression.


Objective 1: Development of Circuit Sketcher - We built a live browser-based prototype of the Circuit Sketcher design software, which uses an intuitive painting and stamping interface that lets users explore both functional and artistic aspects of circuit design. Users simply place component footprint stamps on a canvas and draw circuit lines connecting these components. 

 

We developed basic editing functionalities including duplicate, move, rotate, delete and undo. Component footprints cannot be scaled, however, so that they continue to match actual components for fabrication. Users can import SVG designs from other graphic design software as well as PNGs as background reference images. Once a design is completed, users can share their creations via URL, output to PDF for printing, or output to SVG and DXF for cutting using digital desktop cutting machines. 

 

Objective 2: Toolkits and instructional materials - We tested a variety of conductive materials internally and with our target user groups. We identified an initial set of suitable tools and materials, and are currently working on improving this set. In addition to the materials and tools, we researched optimization of the fabrication process including best practices for determining machine fabrication settings and transferring the cut circuit to the final substrate. Finally, we are currently experimenting with digitally fabricated circuit elements and developing paper-circuit friendly electronic modules.

 

In addition to toolkit materials, we developed instructional materials for teaching users how to use the Circuit Sketcher software as well as the fabrication procedure. Many users found the blank canvas too intimidating, so we developed example projects for following along and partially finished projects to build upon and complete. Others wanted to practice the fabrication procedure so we created a series of practice cut designs. 

 

Objective 3: User testing - To assess the usability and commercial feasibility of our Circuit Sketcher software prototype, toolkit and fabrication process for our target audiences, we conducted user studies and workshops with three different populations?teachers, students, and paper crafters.

 

We conducted user studies with teachers and crafters remotely and gathered data through pre- and post-workshop surveys, as well as digital workbooks to document their progress.  Teachers found the tool to be intuitive and easy-to-use and most reported that they would try this with their students.  They came up with creative solutions for applying it in the classroom and saw value in the software tool alone as a means for students to experiment with and understand circuits.  Two teachers from our user study tried Circuit Sketcher with students in their classrooms, one with a small group of eighth-grade students and another with over 100 sixth-grade students.  

We also worked with students in-person in libraries and an after-school environment .  Students found it fun to make artful circuits.   One was excited to share this with her science teacher.

 

Results from our Phase I studies and workshops are promising: teachers, crafters and students were able to create projects with the Circuit Sketcher software and fabrication methods with varying levels of scaffolding and expressed interest in using these tools again in their future projects. The diversity in artifacts demonstrates the ability of Circuit Sketcher and our paper circuits approach to enable creators of different backgrounds and interests to express themselves and create unique and personalized projects. 

 

After completing the Phase I research, we are confident that we have developed a powerful educational technology for classrooms and informal learning environments, as well as an engaging creativity support tool for craft hobbyists. This tool helps lower the barrier for learning and fabricating circuits, while making electronics accessible and engaging for more diverse audiences, especially underrepresented communities in STEM. 


 

 


Last Modified: 07/26/2022
Modified by: Jie Qi

por.por_txt_cntn:
For this Phase I project, Chibitronics prototyped Circuit Sketcher, a browser-based software tool for the digital design and digital fabrication of circuits on paper.  During Phase I, we met our proposed technical objectives: 1) Designing and developing a circuit design tool for building circuits on paper, 2) Designing and assembling a toolkit of physical materials and instructional materials and 3) Conducting user studies with educators, students, and paper crafters.  We achieved all three of these objectives.  Our participants found Circuit Sketcher to be an accessible and versatile tool for circuit design and fabrication, enabling creative expression.


Objective 1: Development of Circuit Sketcher - We built a live browser-based prototype of the Circuit Sketcher design software, which uses an intuitive painting and stamping interface that lets users explore both functional and artistic aspects of circuit design. Users simply place component footprint stamps on a canvas and draw circuit lines connecting these components. 

 
We developed basic editing functionalities including duplicate, move, rotate, delete and undo. Component footprints cannot be scaled, however, so that they continue to match actual components for fabrication. Users can import SVG designs from other graphic design software as well as PNGs as background reference images. Once a design is completed, users can share their creations via URL, output to PDF for printing, or output to SVG and DXF for cutting using digital desktop cutting machines. 

 
Objective 2: Toolkits and instructional materials - We tested a variety of conductive materials internally and with our target user groups. We identified an initial set of suitable tools and materials, and are currently working on improving this set. In addition to the materials and tools, we researched optimization of the fabrication process including best practices for determining machine fabrication settings and transferring the cut circuit to the final substrate. Finally, we are currently experimenting with digitally fabricated circuit elements and developing paper-circuit friendly electronic modules.

 
In addition to toolkit materials, we developed instructional materials for teaching users how to use the Circuit Sketcher software as well as the fabrication procedure. Many users found the blank canvas too intimidating, so we developed example projects for following along and partially finished projects to build upon and complete. Others wanted to practice the fabrication procedure so we created a series of practice cut designs. 

 
Objective 3: User testing - To assess the usability and commercial feasibility of our Circuit Sketcher software prototype, toolkit and fabrication process for our target audiences, we conducted user studies and workshops with three different populations?teachers, students, and paper crafters.

 
We conducted user studies with teachers and crafters remotely and gathered data through pre- and post-workshop surveys, as well as digital workbooks to document their progress.  Teachers found the tool to be intuitive and easy-to-use and most reported that they would try this with their students.  They came up with creative solutions for applying it in the classroom and saw value in the software tool alone as a means for students to experiment with and understand circuits.  Two teachers from our user study tried Circuit Sketcher with students in their classrooms, one with a small group of eighth-grade students and another with over 100 sixth-grade students.  
We also worked with students in-person in libraries and an after-school environment .  Students found it fun to make artful circuits.   One was excited to share this with her science teacher.

 
Results from our Phase I studies and workshops are promising: teachers, crafters and students were able to create projects with the Circuit Sketcher software and fabrication methods with varying levels of scaffolding and expressed interest in using these tools again in their future projects. The diversity in artifacts demonstrates the ability of Circuit Sketcher and our paper circuits approach to enable creators of different backgrounds and interests to express themselves and create unique and personalized projects. 

 
After completing the Phase I research, we are confident that we have developed a powerful educational technology for classrooms and informal learning environments, as well as an engaging creativity support tool for craft hobbyists. This tool helps lower the barrier for learning and fabricating circuits, while making electronics accessible and engaging for more diverse audiences, especially underrepresented communities in STEM.
